patterns.comment: else if is a common mistake carried over from other languages. it works if you put in a second end, but itâ€™s never what you want.
patterns.name: invalid.deprecated.covscript

patterns.comment: everything being a reserved word, not a value and needing a 'end' is a..
patterns.name: keyword.control.covscript

patterns.comment: contextual smart pair support for block parameters
patterns.name: keyword.control.start-block.covscript

patterns.comment: everything being a method but having a special function is a..
patterns.name: keyword.other.special-method.covscript

patterns.comment: The method pattern comes from the symbol pattern. See there for an explanation.
patterns.name: meta.function.method.with-arguments.covscript

patterns.begin:
(?x)
(?=function\b)                          # optimization to help Oniguruma fail fast
(?<=^|\s)(function)\s+
(
  (?>[a-zA-Z_]\w*(?>\.|::))?      # method prefix
  (?>                               # method name
    [a-zA-Z_]\w*(?>[?!]|=(?!>))?
    |
    ===?|!=|>[>=]?|<=>|<[<=]?|[%&`/\|]|\*\*?|=?~|[-+]@?|\[]=?
  )
)
[ \t]
(?=[ \t]*[^\s#;])                 # make sure the following is not comment
patterns.comment: same as the previous rule, but without parentheses around the arguments
patterns.name: meta.function.method.with-arguments.covscript

patterns.comment: the optional name is just to catch the function also without a method-name
patterns.name: meta.function.method.without-arguments.covscript

patterns.comment: Needs higher precidence than regular expressions.
patterns.name: keyword.operator.assignment.augmented.covscript

patterns.comment: string literal with interpolation and "" delimitor
patterns.name: string.quoted.double.interpolated.covscript

patterns.comment: Cant be named because its not neccesarily an escape.
Cant be named because its not neccesarily an escape.
Cant be named because its not neccesarily an escape.
Cant be named because its not neccesarily an escape.

matches questionmark-letters.

			examples (1st alternation = hex):
			?\x1     ?\x61

			examples (2nd alternation = octal):
			?\0      ?\07     ?\017

			examples (3rd alternation = escaped):
			?\n      ?\b

			examples (4th alternation = meta-ctrl):
			?\C-a    ?\M-a    ?\C-\M-\C-\M-a

			examples (4th alternation = normal):
			?a       ?A       ?0 
			?*       ?"       ?( 
			?.       ?#
			
			
			the negative lookbehind prevents against matching
			p(42.tainted?)
patterns.name: constant.numeric.covscript

patterns.name: string.unquoted.heredoc.covscript

patterns.comment: Mark as namespace separator if double colons followed by capital letter
Mark as method separator if double colons not followed by capital letter
Must come after method and constant separators to prefer double colons
patterns.name: punctuation.separator.other.covscript

patterns.comment: This is kindof experimental. There really is no way to perfectly match all regular variables, but you can pretty well assume that any normal word in certain curcumstances that haven't already been scoped as something else are probably variables, and the advantages beat the potential errors
patterns.name: variable.other.covscript

patterns.comment: We are restrictive in what we allow to go after the comment character to avoid false positives, since the availability of comments depend on regexp flags.
patterns.name: comment.line.number-sign.covscript
